events.originalText: White supremacists murdered James Byrd Jr., an African American, by chaining him behind a pickup truck and dragging him along an asphalt road in Jasper, Texas.
events.subtitle: White supremacy
events.headline: White supremacists murder James Byrd Jr. in Jasper, Texas

events.originalText: The Israeli Air Force attacked a nuclear reactor under the assumption that it was about to start producing plutonium to further an Iraqi nuclear-weapons program.
events.subtitle: Israeli Air Force
events.headline: Israeli Air Force attacks nuclear reactor in Iraq

events.originalText: The inaugural edition of the Cricket World Cup, the premier international championship of men's One Day International cricket, began in England.
events.subtitle: 1975 Cricket World Cup
events.headline: Cricket World Cup kicks off in England

events.originalText: The rock supergroup Blind Faith, featuring Eric Clapton, Steve Winwood and Ginger Baker, played their only UK show in London's Hyde Park in front of 100,000 fans.
events.subtitle: Blind Faith
events.headline: Blind Faith rocks Hyde Park with Eric Clapton

events.originalText: The U.S. Supreme Court ruled in Griswold v. Connecticut that a Connecticut law prohibiting the use of contraceptives violated the "right to marital privacy".
events.subtitle: Supreme Court of the United States
events.headline: U.S. Supreme Court rules in Griswold v. Connecticut

events.originalText: Anti-Jewish riots broke out in the French protectorate in Morocco, during which 44 people were killed and 150 injured.
events.subtitle: 1948 Anti-Jewish riots in Oujda and Jerada
events.headline: Anti-Jewish riots erupt in French Morocco

events.originalText: First World War: The British Army detonated 19 ammonal mines under German lines, killing 10,000 in the deadliest non-nuclear man-made explosion in history.
events.subtitle: World War I
events.headline: British Army detonates deadly mines in WWI

events.originalText: American temperance activist Carrie Nation entered a saloon in Kiowa, Kansas, and destroyed its stock of alcoholic beverages with rocks.
events.subtitle: Temperance movement in the United States
events.headline: Carrie Nation smashes saloon in Kansas

events.originalText: Homer Plessy, a mixed-race man from New Orleans, was arrested for refusing to leave his seat in the "whites-only" car of a train; he lost the resulting court case, Plessy v. Ferguson.
events.subtitle: Homer Plessy
events.headline: Homer Plessy arrested in segregation case

events.originalText: The Reform Act, which is widely credited with launching modern democracy in the United Kingdom, received royal assent.
events.subtitle: Reform Act 1832
events.headline: Reform Act receives royal assent in UK

events.originalText: Journalist Mariano Moreno published Argentina's first newspaper, the Gazeta de Buenos-Ayres.
events.subtitle: Mariano Moreno
events.headline: Mariano Moreno publishes Argentina's first newspaper

events.originalText: Virginia statesman Richard Henry Lee presented a resolution to the Second Continental Congress, calling for the Thirteen Colonies to declare independence from Great Britain.
events.subtitle: Colony of Virginia
events.headline: Richard Henry Lee calls for independence from Britain

events.originalText: An earthquake registering approximately 7.5 Mw caused Port Royal, Jamaica, to sink below sea level and killed approximately 5,000 people.
events.subtitle: 1692 Jamaica earthquake
events.headline: Earthquake sinks Port Royal, Jamaica

events.originalText: The Petition of Right, a major English constitutional document that set out specific liberties of individuals, received royal assent from King Charles I.
events.subtitle: Petition of Right
events.headline: Petition of Right receives royal assent in England

events.originalText: Roman emperor Theodosius II married Aelia Eudocia (pictured), who later helped to protect Greek pagans and Jews from persecution.
events.subtitle: Theodosius II
events.headline: Theodosius II marries Aelia Eudocia
